(42) 190 and 193).weekDiscussion of these Papers was adjourned until the following2. The War Cabinet had a discussion, which is recorded inthe Secretary's Standard File of War Cabinet Conclusions.3. The War Cabinet had before them a Memorandum by theSecretary of State for Foreign Affairs (W.M. (42) 191).The War Cabinet agreed as follows': (1) We should offer half a million General Service respiratorsto Russia forthwith, the sacrifice being shared propor-tionately by all users. It would probably be necessaryfor these half million respirators to be suppliedunassembled.(2) The Foreign Secretary, as Chairman of the Allied SuppliesExecutive, was asked to settle, in consultation with theMinisters concerned, any questions as regards the supplyof CD. stores.(Note. Subsequent to the Meeting, the Ministers concernedagreed that the following should be offered to theRussians : 200 tons a week of sodium cyanide,120 tons of chlorine,2,000 tons of tropical bleach.As regards other items, the Russian representatives should be informed that, owing to the small quantitiesavailable, we had nothing worth while to offer them.)4. The Secretary of State for the Colonies said that, as lord Gort had not yet reached Malta, it had not been possible tomake a statement in Parliament this week of the latter 's appoint-ment to succeed General Dobbie. He felt that it would be impossibleto avoid making some statement on the subject during the courseof the next two or three days.The War Cabinet Agreed that no statement should be made until Lord Goithad arrived in Malta, and took note that the PrimeMinister might refer to this matter in his. broadcast on sunday.Great George Street, S.W. 1,May 7, 1942.
